### Description

Add conditional compilation for MacCatalyst in https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/main/src/Core/src/Handlers/WebView/WebViewHandler.cs.

Add "|| MacCatalyst" on lines 15 and 31.
Add "&& MacCatalyst" on line 9

In https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77170252/requestcapturemediapermission-for-wkwebview-in-maui-ios/77200328?noredirect=1#comment136198064_77200328, the given solution works only on iOS and not on MacCatalyst. The suspected reason is that the conditional compilation happens only for iOS.

No test case is needed.

issue.title: [regression/8.0.0] Entry bug—height grows on every input event

labels.name: area/layout 🔲
labels.description: StackLayout, GridLayout, ScrollView, ContentView, AbsoluteLayout, FlexLayout, ContentPresenter

labels.name: s/verified
labels.description: Verified / Reproducible Issue ready for Engineering Triage

labels.name: i/regression
labels.description: This issue described a confirmed regression on a currently supported version

issue.body:
### Description

If we use an `Entry` alongside a `RoundRectangle` inside a `Grid`, like so:
```
<Grid>
    <RoundRectangle Fill="Red" />
    <Entry x:Name="MyEntry" Text="{Binding MyText}" />
</Grid>
```

The Entry's height will grow on every input event. [See demo gif in reproduction repo](https://github.com/aleksandervalle/maui-entry-bug-repro).

We have been using `RoundRectangle` like this instead `Border` because of bugs in `Border` (which may have been fixed in RC2).

This is definitely a regression from .NET 7. I'm not sure whether or not this worked on .NET 8 RC1, as we couldn't get our app running on RC1.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone repo https://github.com/aleksandervalle/maui-entry-bug-repro
2. Run project on an Android emulator
3. Write in the Entry input field

### Link to public reproduction project repository

https://github.com/aleksandervalle/maui-entry-bug-repro

### Version with bug

8.0.0-rc.2.9373

### Is this a regression from previous behavior?

Yes, this used to work in .NET MAUI

### Last version that worked well

7.0.304

### Affected platforms

Android

### Affected platform versions

Android 14, API 34 (not tested on iOS)

### Did you find any workaround?

We're exploring whether or not the `Border` bugs that made us use this `RoundRectangle` method have been fixed. If so, the workaround for us will be to go back to using `Border`.

### Relevant log output

_No response_

comment.body:
FYI, this seem to affect `RoundRectangle`s further up the tree as well. Fixed our input component by replacing `RoundRectangle` with `Border`:

```
<Border>
    <Entry x:Name="MyEntry" Text="{Binding MyText}" />
</Border>
```

But while the input component itself no longer appeared to grow, an outer wrapping container still grew on input events on the inner `Entry`.

Replacing `RoundRectangle` with `Border` in the outer wrapping container fixed the issue.

issue.title: CollectionView Layout breaks if IsVisible starts as False
issue.body:
### Description

Using an MVVM architecture with the CommunityToolkit.Mvvm package, if a CollectionView using the vertical LinearItemsLayout has the IsVisible property bound to a value that starts as false, the layout will not apply properly on Windows. Specifically, it ends up just displaying horizontally.

I tested this using the MVVM approach and toolkit, however I suspect the issue would persist in any project where the CollectionView starts invisible.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create new MAUI app
2. Add CommunityToolkit.Mvvm package
3. Add a CollectionView to the page
4. Populate with any arbitrary data
5. Add <CollectionView.ItemsLayout> node, with <LinearItemsLayout Orientation="Vertical" /> within
6. Create a bool _visible = false field in the view model, with the [ObservableProperty] attribute
7. Add an IsVisible="{Binding Visible}" attribute to the CollectionView
8. Create a Button node with a Command to set Visible to true
9. Build and run the app, click the button

Expected outcome: The CollectionView appears in a vertical orientation
Actual outcome: The CollectionView appears with a horizontal orientation

### Link to public reproduction project repository

_No response_

### Version with bug

8.0.0-rc.2.9373

### Is this a regression from previous behavior?

Not sure, did not test other versions

### Last version that worked well

Unknown/Other

### Affected platforms

Windows

### Affected platform versions

Windows SDK 10.0.17763.0

### Did you find any workaround?

_No response_

### Relevant log output

_No response_

issue.title: [WinUI] TemplatedItemsList and underlying ListView UI elements are disconnected, creates phantom views.
issue.body: ### Description TL;DR Every time you add a new item to a WinUI ListView that's bound to an ObservableCollection, two Cells are created and only one is outputted to the screen. - When a MAUI WinUI ListView gets created, the attached virtual ItemSource is taken, transformed into an ObservableCollection if it's not already, and set as a CollectionViewSource for the underlying WinUI ListView, https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/3c0ff6735c6b259a17cdef31f7ebce8dea1e0a30/src/Compatibility/Core/src/Windows/ListViewRenderer.cs#L127-L164 - If you already have items in your item source, the VisualRenderers will start to invoke and request elements, which in turn causes WinUI to invoke elements to be created. These will result in the first `Cell` items to be created and put into the WinUI ListView. Note that these cells are not directly referenced or run through TemplatedItemsList, so according to it, these Cells are `null`. - If you add another item to the ItemSource (and the ItemSource is observable), a `OnProxyCollectionChanged` handler event is fired, https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/3c0ff6735c6b259a17cdef31f7ebce8dea1e0a30/src/Controls/src/Core/TemplatedItemsList.cs#L998-L1007 - This creates a new `Cell` based on the underlying template. - Once that's done, another OnCollectionChanged is fired to the ListViewRenderer. https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/3c0ff6735c6b259a17cdef31f7ebce8dea1e0a30/src/Controls/src/Core/TemplatedItemsList.cs#L1104 - While the event contains the new ViewCell as created in the last method, this method doesn't use it. Instead, it calls on the underlying WinUI List to update its layout (which, based on the ItemsSource having the new items, will then generate cells) - https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/3c0ff6735c6b259a17cdef31f7ebce8dea1e0a30/src/Compatibility/Core/src/Windows/ListViewRenderer.cs#L238 - This will then call for _new_ `Cell` objects that are then inserted in the real WinUI list. This, I believe, creates two separate lists of given Cells: One in the native WinUI view, and one in TemplatedItemsList, that are not directly linked, with TemplatedItemsList generating Cells that point to nothing. Beyond potential memory considerations, this causes issues with tooling. New Items inserted into an ItemsSource are processed twice, once in TemplatedItemsList and again by WinUI, creating two distinct Cells. https://github.com/dotnet/maui/assets/898335/1a6b3737-c499-416f-9198-16171440c0dd You can see this manifest with XAML Hot Reload. The initial items in the ListView are not represented in the Live Visual Tree, because they are never registered to VisualDiagnostics.OnChildrenAdded. That gets called in SetupContent, which isn't called for initial items in the list. https://github.com/dotnet/maui/blob/3c0ff6735c6b259a17cdef31f7ebce8dea1e0a30/src/Controls/src/Core/ListView/ListView.cs#L441-L453 New items do get called through TemplatedItemsList, so they do invoke SetupContent and do get added to LVT. However, these cells are not the ones shown to the user. If you try to make Hot Reload changes to them, while they appear in LVT, they do not appear in the running app. This is because there are two Cells for every given item, and we're editing the one within TemplatedItemsList, which is not the one shown on screen. Those items do exist and XAML Hot Reload is doing the correct thing here. This happens in all versions of MAUI. ### Steps to Reproduce Copy the reproduction project into the MAUI Sandbox Project in the repo. ### Link to public reproduction project repository https://github.com/drasticactions/MauiRepros/tree/main/MauiListViewTest ### Version with bug 7.0.96 ### Is this a regression from previous behavior? No, this is something new ### Last version that worked well Unknown/Other ### Affected platforms Windows ### Affected platform versions _No response_ ### Did you find any workaround? _No response_ ### Relevant log output _No response_

issue.title: iOS Binding Does Nothing

labels.name: area/tooling ⚙️
labels.description: XAML & C# Hot Reload, XAML Editor, Live Visual Tree, Live Preview, Debugging

labels.name: s/needs-attention
labels.description: Issue has more information and needs another look

labels.name: partner/macios
labels.description: Issues for the Mac / iOS SDK

issue.body:
### Description

I can successfully get an iOS Objective-C library (.a file) to bind following the Xamarin binding tutorial found here: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/xamarin/cross-platform/macios/binding/objective-c-libraries.
I also used the library that the tutorial recommended to follow which is located here:  https://github.com/xamarin/ios-samples/tree/master/BindingSample

Now I am trying to do the same for MAUI. When selecting a MAUI iOS binding library, adding the ios static library, and copying in the same code, it says it compiled but it has not actually done anything. The dll produced has no functions present when decompiling and checking it. Its almost like VS does not recognize that it is a binding library setup and basically does nothing.

Things I have tried for a fix:
1) Creating a new MAUI ios binding template using the dotnet commands in powershell
2) Downloading a MAUI ios binding example and trying to compile that directly such as: https://github.com/drasticactions/WebP.Touch/tree/net6-port/WebP.Touch
3) Changing from a .netcore 7 to .netcore6 project which fails too.

Am I missing something critical for MAUI template to work in comparison to how XAMARIN does it?

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create new MAUI iOS Binding Library in Visual Studio 22
2. Load in a native iOS library (.a) and add any exports to the code
3. Compile and then decompile DLL to see now functions available

### Link to public reproduction project repository

https://github.com/Tazzi3/MAUI-ObjC-Binding

### Version with bug

7.0 (current)

### Last version that worked well

Unknown/Other

### Affected platforms

iOS

### Affected platform versions

all iOS

### Did you find any workaround?

No work around.

### Relevant log output

_No response_

comment.body:
> In iOS binding, copy all .a files and ApiDefinition.cs/StructsAndEnums.cs files, the iOSBinding project can compile success, but add it to iOS maui project (`<ProjectReference Include="..\iOS_BindingLibrary\iOS_BindingLibrary.csproj" />`), it can't find any api which was defined in ApiDefinition.cs.

There's a known issue where intellisense in the IDE won't work, but the build will actually succeed. Can you try building the project and see if that works? One workaround is to reference the binding assembly directly instead of the binding project, in which case intellisense will work as expected.
